title: How Trump’s convention has become a crucial play for the suburbs.

content: It is President Trump’s clearest path to re-election: winning back the suburbs in a handful of swing states that drifted from the Republican Party in the 2018 midterms. description: Heji Shin’s striking, discomfiting work poses an important question for the contemporary age: What do we expect art to do, and does the artist have a responsibility to do it?
content: “WE PUT A kind of call out for cocks. And they brought them. They’re beautiful. I mean, they’re extremely, extremely beautiful,” says the photographer Heji Shin in the midst of her latest shoot, her first since the Covid-19 lockdown: large-format studio portraits — “very sharp, very shiny” — of bellicose roosters. Two prints from the series, titled “Big Cocks,” recently appeared in a group show at Galerie Buchholz in Berlin. Roosters have long been associated with masculinity (though, in fact, they don’t have penises, Shin informs me); in an era in which violence tends to be systemic or “tactical,” she writes to me later, “the short-lived outbursts of angry cock energy look Hellenistic and virile.”

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: The Dual History of Poisonous Flowers
description: From ancient times through today, the same blooms used to harm have also proved healing.
content: THE FLOWERS POINT straight down, a chandelier’s worth, turned ostentatiously away from the sun. They are Brugmansia by genus and angel’s trumpet in parlance, with elongated buds that open into blaring mouths. In South America, the tree that bears them is called el borrachero, or “the drunk-maker,” in part because of the blooms’ dizzying night perfume of fermented lemons, said to induce crazed dreams. And more: Parts of the plant, when crushed, yield scopolamine, a.k.a. burundanga, a.k.a. devil’s breath — a psychoactive alkaloid deployed by criminals, via a spiked drink or a puff in the face, to disable free will. It is said to transform victims into dutiful servants who revive hours later, bereft of all their belongings and any memory of what they’ve done.

description: The deafening silence of not having sports provided a powerful message from athletes demanding racial justice, after kneeling and slogans on jerseys seemed to have lost potency.
content: It was the silence that spoke loudest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Bill & Ted Face the Music’ Review: Be Adequate to Each Other
description: Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter travel through time to save reality and redeem the honor of Generation X.
content: “Bill & Ted Face the Music” sounds like more of a reckoning than it is. It would be unbearable to think that William Preston and Theodore Logan, the goofballs first incarnated by Alex Winter and Keanu Reeves more than 30 years ago, could be candidates for cancellation. And though they may be longer in the tooth and heavier in the jowl than they used to be — as so many of us are — the dudes retain their essential innocence. They are still friendly avatars of nontoxic masculinity. No serious misdeeds resurface from their various time travels that demand judgment in the harsh light of the present.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Wise
title: Here’s What America’s Covid-Era Classrooms Look Like
description: We asked educators to show us how they are preparing their classrooms to teach amid the coronavirus.
content: This will be a school year unlike any other, that much is clear. Educators, parents and students across the country are returning to in-person and virtual classrooms shaped by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Three Trump Supporters Have a New Target: Germany
description: The United States needs allies. Punishing Berlin over a Russian gas pipeline is a needless provocation.
content: There is something profoundly skewed in America’s foreign relations when senators threaten “crushing legal and economic sanctions” against a port city of a close European ally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Bill Arnett, Collector and Promoter of Little-Known Black Art, Dies at 81
description: In the 1980s and ’90s, he traveled Southern byways to find brilliant works by self-taught African-American artists who often used scavenged materials.
content: Bill Arnett had spent two decades collecting and dealing antiquities from around the world — African art was his passion — when, in 1986, he had an epiphany in Birmingham, Ala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: On ‘Smile,’ Katy Perry Finds Purpose (and Pitfalls) in the Past
description: The singer and songwriter is no longer at the gravitational center of American pop music. But on her sixth album, she tries to add brightness to a dark moment.
content: It is either auspicious, or unfortunate, that Katy Perry is releasing her sixth album, “Smile,” the same week that her titanically successful 2010 record “Teenage Dream” is celebrating its 10th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘The Binge’ Review: They’ll Drink to That
description: In this parody of the “Purge” movies, drugs and booze are banned except for one 12-hour period a year.
content: Here’s an equation for third-period math: Take “Superbad,” “Booksmart,” and, hell, any teen-party movie, add in a useless overarching conceit, subtract all originality. The result is “The Binge,” a new Hulu original that is only exceptional in its mind-numbing inanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Nina Siegal
title: 17th-Century Dutch Painting Is Stolen. Again.
description: “Two Laughing Boys” by Frans Hals has been taken from a museum in the Netherlands, after having been stolen in 1988 and again in 2011.
content: AMSTERDAM — A 17th-century painting by the Golden Age master Frans Hals was stolen from the wall of a museum in the Netherlands early Wednesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: With Wisconsin Unrest as Backdrop, Republicans Intensify Law-and-Order Message
description: On the third day of the convention, Vice President Mike Pence and other Republicans portrayed Democrats as tolerant of violence and riots. And they continued to try to soften President Trump’s image.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans used the third night of their convention on Wednesday to amplify warnings of violence and lawlessness under Democratic leadership, trying to capitalize on the worsening unrest in Wisconsin to reclaim moderate voters who might be reluctant to hand President Trump a second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise and Ellen Almer Durston
title: How Chaos in Kenosha Is Already Swaying Some Voters in Wisconsin
description: As residents see fires and looting, some worry that local Democratic leaders are failing to keep control of the situation.
content: John Geraghty, a 41-year-old worker in a tractor factory, has barely paid attention to the presidential race or the conventions. Every day he focuses on survival: getting his son to sports practice, working at his job where he now wears a mask, and getting home to sleep, only to start over again the next day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin, Natasha Frost and Sandra Stevenson
title: Hurricane Laura, President Trump, Baby Dinosaurs: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Full Transcript: Mike Pence’s R.N.C. Speech
description: The vice president in a lengthy speech at Fort McHenry said the 2020 election was a choice of “whether America remains America.”
content: Vice President Mike Pence on Wednesday made a case that President Trump is all that is standing in the way of the United States devolving not only into anarchy but also into a state that cancels the country’s essential nature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: The TikTok FOMO Is Real
description: A teenage reader says that the video sharing app is stoking feelings of social exclusion.
content: As a teen, TikTok creates stress in my life. When I hang out with friends, they often ask if I want to make a TikTok with them. I never suggest it, but it nearly always comes up. I want to be nice and say yes, but then I worry that other friends will see the clip and feel excluded that they weren’t part of it. At times, TikToks have made me feel separate from my friends, and I don’t want to make anyone else feel that. How can I be polite and still respect my friends’ feelings?
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Angels to American Cuisine
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE APPOINTMENT, by Katharina Volckmer. (Avid Reader, $22.) In a furious comic monologue to her gynecologist , the German-born narrator of this debut novel riffs on national shame, family secrets, sex and more with a disregard for propriety worthy of Alexander Portnoy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: What if Facebook Is the Real ‘Silent Majority’?
description: Right-wing influencers are dominating the political discussion on Facebook, raising questions about whether it will translate into electoral success in November.
content: Listen, liberals. If you don’t think Donald Trump can get re-elected in November, you need to spend more time on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: As Young Black Athletes Call for Racial Awakening, Some N.F.L. Retirees Declare Fealty to ‘Winner’ Trump
description: Several former athletes and coaches including Lou Holtz have appeared at the R.N.C. to deliver a message that the party wants to project — that the president is not racist. Many current Black athletes do not agree.
content: On one of the most consequential nights in recent sports history — when a player-led boycott forced the N.B.A. to postpone playoff games — the Republican National Convention offered pro-Trump testimonials from a retired Notre Dame coach and a former N.F.L. player facing insider-trading charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Hurricane Laura in Pictures
description: Photographers are on the ground in Texas and Louisiana documenting the damage from the storm.
content: Hurricane Laura made landfall near Cameron, La., early Thursday as a Category 4 hurricane, delivering a barrage of 150-mile-per-hour winds and a surge of water. The storm weakened as it moved inland but remained destructive with strong winds and heavy rain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Deceptive robocalls try to frighten Detroit residents about voting by mail.
description: The calls suggest that voting-by-mail exposes personal information, a lie, in what officials said was an apparent effort to suppress vote
content: The authorities in Michigan said on Thursday they were investigating deceptive robocalls targeting Detroit residents in what appeared to be an effort to deter them from voting by mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Félix Fénéon, the Collector-Anarchist Who Was Seurat’s First Champion
description: The Museum of Modern Art reopens with an exemplary show devoted to an essential figure who multitasked his way through the aesthetic and political ferment of Belle Époque Paris.
content: Every exhibition tells a story, usually about an artist or groups of them. Occasionally, however, some shows focus on non-artists: individuals who work as art dealers, curators, critics or collectors. Essential to a functioning art world, they don’t make things. They make things happen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein, Sopan Deb and Alan Blinder
title: One N.B.A. Team Walked Out. A Generation of Athletes Followed.
description: More games were halted in basketball, baseball and hockey, and the messages from athletes reverberated beyond the sports world.
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — George Hill is hardly the biggest star in professional basketball. But he was the one who took the lead when a handful of players on the Milwaukee Bucks began talking about the police shooting of Jacob Blake a few days earlier in Wisconsin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: How to Watch the Republican National Convention
description: President Trump will accept the nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.
content: After eight intense nights of programming, the 2020 conventions will come to an end on Thursday: President Trump will formally accept the Republican nomination, and the general election season will officially begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Power and Passage: New Science Fiction and Fantasy
description: A story collection offers a cleareyed survey of the Black American experience, and a debut novel traverses hundreds of versions of Earth.
content: The discourse about reading fiction during the pandemic has followed two broad tracks: There are those who take comfort in the activity, and those who have found reading impossibly difficult. I belong to the latter camp, but I’m all the more excited to share the following books, which, while very different in genre and mode, shook me out of listless distraction with their originality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Hurricane Laura tore through part of the U.S. already struggling with the pandemic.
content: Hurricane Laura slammed into the Louisiana and Texas coasts overnight, sending residents in areas hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic scrambling to find shelter. The hurricane was among the strongest storms ever to hit the U.S., and more than 500,000 residents in its path were urged to leave their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Horberry
title: Reopened Schools Find Health Risks in Water After Covid-19 Lockdowns
description: A number of schools found the bacteria that causes Legionnaires’ disease in their water, and experts say more should expect to see it.
content: The new coronavirus is not the only illness that teachers, students, parents and staff will have to worry about as some schools attempt to reopen this fall. Legionella could lurk in the water supplies of school buildings, and some measures to keep people in schools safe from coronavirus may even increase risks from deadly illnesses caused by the bacteria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Donald G. McNeil Jr
title: My Job? Telling People What Happens Next
description: I spend my time talking to experts, trying to envision what the future of the coronavirus crisis looks like. There aren’t a lot of rules on how to do this.
content: Times Insider explains who we are and what we do, and delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how our journalism comes together.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Plenty of evidence this week that we’re living in a boom time for thoughtful, powerful nature writing. “Vesper Flights” collects essays by Helen Macdonald, whom you likely know from her internationally best-selling memoir, “H Is for Hawk.” In “The Bird Way,” Jennifer Ackerman takes a detailed look at the lives of birds — including their parenting strategies — like the bowerbird, the cuckoo and the kea. From the sky to the sea, with another international best seller: Patrik Svensson’s “The Book of Eels,” which combines elements of memoir with an examination of the slithery creatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: Late Housing Payments and Coronavirus
description: Landlords are negotiating payment plans, but rent and mortgage debt is rising.
content: Nearly six months into the pandemic, the share of American homeowners and renters who have missed or been late with their monthly housing payments is holding steady, despite government stimulus initiatives and protections including the CARES Act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliana Kim
title: The M.T.A.’s Doomsday Budget Plan
description: Without federal aid, the agency said, it would need to reduce subway and bus service by 40 percent to address its deficit.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Turkey Braces for Yet Another Currency Crisis
description: A sharp drop in the value of the lira is testing businesses and residents while they are coping with the pandemic.
content: When the Turkish lira plunged to a new low against the dollar and euro this month, Hakan Bulgurlu did not panic. This was not the first time that Mr. Bulgurlu, the chief executive of Arcelik, a Turkish maker of home appliances, had steered through a currency crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geneva Abdul
title: A Rising Women’s Team Looks Past the Pandemic
description: In three seasons, Bordeaux rose from obscurity to a top-three place in France. The coronavirus affected its momentum, but not its plans.
content: PARIS — Khadija Shaw sensed opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Motavalli
title: Soon, the Kitty Litter Will Come by Electric Truck
description: With deliveries surging during the pandemic, carriers like UPS and FedEx and companies like Amazon are renewing their push toward electric vehicles.
content: Going back years, you might have been able to spot a truck from the likes of FedEx and UPS, and more recently Amazon, that ran on electricity. But most of these were small, short test runs that left the internal-combustion status quo in place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Move Over, Sustainable Travel. Regenerative Travel Has Arrived.
description: Can a post-vaccine return to travel be smarter and greener than it was before March 2020? Some in the tourism industry are betting on it.
content: Tourism, which grew faster than the global gross domestic product for the past nine years, has been decimated by the pandemic. Once accounting for 10 percent of employment worldwide, the sector is poised to shed 121 million jobs, with losses projected at a minimum of $3.4 trillion, according to the World Travel & Tourism Council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Sets Stage for Longer Periods of Lower Rates
description: Jerome H. Powell said the central bank would focus its efforts on fostering a strong labor market while tolerating higher inflation.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, announced a major shift in how the central bank guides the economy, signaling it will make job growth pre-eminent and will not raise interest rates to guard against coming inflation just because the unemployment rate is low.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
title: Israeli Officer Need Not Have Shot Autistic Palestinian, Commander Says
description: The commander testified that the man his partner killed, Iyad al-Hallaq, was not resisting and posed no danger, in a case that ignited protests against police brutality.
content: JERUSALEM — An Israeli police officer who gunned down a Palestinian man who had autism in the Old City of Jerusalem in May defied an order to hold his fire even though the man posed no danger to anyone, his commander has told investigators, according to people briefed on the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Stephen Colbert Refuses to Watch Night 3 of the R.N.C.
description: “Why should we watch their reality show if it doesn’t reflect our reality?” the “Late Show” host asked on Wednesday. “Why subject ourselves to their lies that stick to your soul like hot tar?"
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Chelsea Brasted and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Many Fear the Worst as Forecasters Issue Dire Warnings for Hurricane Laura
description: Winds of about 150 miles per hour and a storm surge that meteorologists are calling “unsurvivable” are expected to barrage the Louisiana and Texas coasts as it makes landfall.
content: LAFAYETTE, La. — More than 500,000 residents in Louisiana and Texas were urged to flee their homes on Wednesday as Hurricane Laura roared toward the Gulf Coast, fueling grave warnings that the storm would deliver a calamitous assault with powerful winds and a storm surge that meteorologists declared “unsurvivable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Sanders, M.D
title: A Strange Rash Had Doctors Stumped. Was It an Insect Bite?
description: After what felt like a sting, a red blotch grew and darkened on his shin. And then a twin rash somehow showed up on the other leg.
content: The 73-year-old man looked up at the clear summer sky — the morning was nearly gone. He had finished mowing the main part of his lawn and was trimming the edges near the shrubbery with the weed wacker. He wanted to finish before the sun and heat made the work too hard. Suddenly he felt a sharp sting on the lower part of his shin. He glanced down at his bare leg. Nothing there. He still had the hedges to trim, so he kept working. He quickly finished the needed pruning, then moved on to the inside tasks he had planned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: German Automotive Giant Admits It Was a Nazi Accomplice
description: The company, Continental, is the latest to offer a detailed exposé of its wartime use of slave labor and other crimes.
content: FRANKFURT — The auto parts maker Continental became the latest German company to issue a confessional study of its Nazi past Thursday, saying it was “a pillar of the National Socialist armaments and war economy” that employed around 10,000 slave laborers, often in inhumane conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Walter Lure, Guitarist for a ‘Mythical’ Punk Band, Dies at 71
description: With the Heartbreakers, a shooting star in New York’s punk rock scene, he was a more proficient guitarist than many of his peers. Then came a very unpunk second act.
content: Walter Lure, who played rhythm guitar for the Heartbreakers, a pioneering band of the 1970s New York punk scene, and who had a most unpunk second career on Wall Street, died on Aug. 21 at in Queens. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Turner
title: ‘All Together Now’ Review: A Song as a Source of Hope
description: In this sweet and scrappy film, Auliʻi Cravalho plays a young woman torn between following her dreams and her loyalty to her mother.
content: There is a particular skill in presenting a character who is nearly flawless without turning her into a staid saint. In Brett Haley’s sweet and scrappy teen Netflix drama “All Together Now,” Amber Appleton (Auliʻi Cravalho) checks so many boxes of trait perfection (she volunteers at a retirement community, teaches E.S.L. classes, etc.) that a worse film would become a hagiography. But Haley’s directing has a gentility, and Cravalho (who was introduced to movie audiences as the title voice in Disney’s “Moana”) gives Amber a visceral humanity that elevates the intermittently uneven screenplay.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live Updates: Trump Barely Mentions Kenosha in Speech, and Only as Violent
description: The president suggested that the Wisconsin city, which has been roiled by protests and violence this week, had succumbed to “mob rule.”
content: President Trump made only a glancing reference to Kenosha, Wis., in his speech on Thursday accepting the Republican nomination for a second term, linking it to other American cities where protests against systemic racism and police brutality have sometimes turned violent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: White House Wants Companies to Foot Payroll Tax Bill for Workers
description: The Treasury Department has not been willing to issue guidance making it clear that companies will be on the hook for deferred taxes, further delaying crucial information for businesses.
content: WASHINGTON — A debate between the White House and the Treasury Department over President Trump’s payroll tax suspension has delayed crucial information about how the executive order will be carried out, according to people familiar with the matter, leaving businesses across the country uncertain about how to proceed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Douglas A.J. Latchford, Khmer Antiquities Expert, Dies at 88
description: A leading collector of Cambodian relics, he was credited with helping preserve Khmer culture. He was also charged with trafficking in looted treasures.
content: Douglas A.J. Latchford, a pre-eminent collector of Cambodian antiquities who earned praise for his scholarly works on Khmer Empire art, only to be indicted last year by American prosecutors for illicitly trafficking in the selfsame objects, died on Aug. 2 at his home in Bangkok. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Perlstein
title: How Much Can 1968 Tell Us About 2020?
description: Drawing parallels between the riots of the 1960s and the protests of today may only be taking us further from the truth, the historian Rick Perlstein writes.
content: I was awakened, early on May 29, by a reporter asking what I thought about the president’s latest tweet; that was how I first learned the most powerful man in the world had just said of the nationwide disturbances breaking out over the police murder of George Floyd, “When the looting starts, the shooting starts.” It portended a busy week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck, Thomas Kaplan and Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Says Trump Is ‘Rooting for More Violence’ Amid Kenosha Unrest
description: As Republicans sensed a political opportunity, the Democratic nominee sought to turn attention back to the pandemic and highlighted the president’s tendency to inflame volatile situations.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Thursday accused President Trump of “rooting for more violence” at a moment of national unrest over racism and police brutality, offering one of his most extensive responses yet to the Republican argument that he would be a weak leader on law enforcement and criminal justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Chee
title: My Family’s Shrouded History Is Also a National One for Korea
description: Decades after the war ended, scars left by the Japanese occupation persist for millions of Koreans and Korean-Americans, including the author Alexander Chee.
content: In the latest article from “Beyond the World War II We Know,” a series by The Times that documents lesser-known stories from World War II, the author Alexander Chee looks back at the dark legacy of the Japanese occupation of Korea — and a once-unknown personal connection to it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Justice Department to Investigate Jacob Blake Shooting
description: Protests continued for a fourth night in Kenosha, and Wisconsin’s attorney general gave new details about the police shooting of Jacob Blake.
content: This briefing has ended. Follow our latest coverage of the unrest in Kenosha, Wis., and elsewhere here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Madea’s Farewell Play’ and ‘Rising Phoenix’
description: A recording of Tyler Perry’s final show as Madea debuts on BET+. And a new Netflix documentary looks at the history of the Paralympics.
content: TYLER PERRY’S MADEA’S FAREWELL PLAY Stream on BET+. Last year, Tyler Perry threw on his gray wig, lipstick and thick, square glasses, and hit the road: He was going to retire his most famous character, Madea, but first he was taking her on a final tour. The show he presented, “Madea’s Farewell Play,” covers familiar Madea territory: wisecracks, music and a plot built on a law school graduation that brings the family back together — comfort food for fans who stream this recorded version. “That old broad has been good to me, so who knows — maybe one day I’ll tell the story of Madea in the ’70s and hire a real actress to play the role,” Perry wrote in an essay in The New York Times last year. “But the time of playing her has come to an end.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and John Ismay
title: Sailor Questioned in Suspected Arson Aboard Navy Warship
description: It took four days in July to extinguish the fire on the Bonhomme Richard, which rendered the ship inoperative.
content: WASHINGTON — Federal investigators have questioned a sailor for suspected arson in the fire that engulfed the warship Bonhomme Richard in July, according to a senior Navy official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels and Michael Gonchar
title: ‘Nice White Parents’ Discussion Guide
description: This companion guide invites families, students and educators to have a conversation about the goals of public education in America … and the relationship between race, social class and a quality education.
content: The podcast “Nice White Parents” largely focuses on the story of one Brooklyn middle school that opened in 1968 — and how white parents have influenced the trajectory of this school over and over, even when their children didn’t attend it. But the issues the podcast raises via this one case study make it a meaningful opportunity to explore the complicated realities of race, privilege and power across all American schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Darlington
title: Wildfires, Pandemic, Earthquakes. What’s Next for California?
description: Nature seems to be ganging up on the Golden State.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — Every other week for the past 18 years, my wife and I have made a five-hour round-trip drive between here and Mendocino County. She has a health care practice in both places, so our rural home isn’t a retreat; nonetheless, like others who had the option, when the pandemic kicked in we opted for the country, where social distance is axiomatic and anxiety less likely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: What if the First Coronavirus Vaccines Aren’t the Best?
description: Dozens of research groups around the world are playing the long game, convinced that their experimental vaccines will be cheaper and more powerful than the ones leading the race today.
content: Seven months into the coronavirus crisis, with more than 30 vaccines rapidly advancing through the rigorous stages of clinical trials, a surprising number of research groups are placing bets on some that have not yet been given to a single person.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Curtis Rush
title: The Islanders’ Goalie Entered With a Shutout Streak. He Left on the Bench.
description: Semyon Varlamov was pulled after allowing three goals on 10 shots in a Game 2 loss to Philadelphia, throwing the goaltending position into question the day before a tiebreaking Game 3.
content: TORONTO — Suddenly, the Islanders’ focus has shifted, from the confidence in a franchise record-setting goaltender, to having concerns about how Semyon Varlamov will bounce back from his worst performance of the N.H.L. postseason on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: A Perk for N.Y.’s Richest Areas: First Dibs on Top Public Schools
description: New York City gives students a shot at nearly all high schools across the city — except for a handful of top schools in Manhattan.
content: On paper, Tiffani Torres looked like a strong candidate for one of New York City’s highest-performing, most selective public high schools. She had high test scores and excellent grades. “I was a good fit for what the school was looking for,” Tiffani said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Parenting in Front of a Live Audience of In-laws
description: Micromanaging my husband, I realized how much I still craved my parents’ approval.
content: Somewhere in rural Pennsylvania, my husband and I whisper-argue on a mattress strewn across the floor. His hand gestures say, “Lower your voice.” Mine say, “I’m a big-haired Spanish woman from Jersey. Fat chance.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: Don’t Be Dense, Beware Mike Pence
description: Just the man you don’t want to see next in line.
content: It’s possible you failed to notice, but the Republican convention has a theme for each night. The list sounds a little like a Lord-of-the-Rings theme park: Land of Promise, Land of Opportunity, Land of Heroes and Land of Greatness.

title: Tracking the Suspect in the Fatal Kenosha Shootings
description: Footage appears to show a teenager shooting three people during protests in Wisconsin. We tracked his movements that night.
content: A teenager who walked among protesters in Kenosha, Wis., carrying a military-style semi-automatic rifle was arrested and faces a charge of first-degree intentional homicide in connection with shootings that left two people dead on Tuesday night.

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Check out an engrossing new documentary series, or the latest installment of a pop culture institution.

author: By Kristen Bateman
title: You’re Beginning to Look Dull
description: How to get a healthy glow even if you’ve barely laid eyes on the sun all summer.
content: It has been a weird summer, many of us cooped up indoors, and our skin has noticed. Now, in these last weeks of the season, skin care obsessives as well as the more laid-back among us are getting sick of the dull skin that has become something of a hallmark of the pandemic.
